blocks.body:
As a warm-up for this blog let’s start with a quick trick in PowerBI. I think it is one of the most useful solutions regarding the visualization part of creating user-friendly reports.

**The requirement:** I want a visualization to show data only if something is selected from the table/slicer above it (in this case row). I would say this will be like a drop-down/drill-through to details but on our terms. In today’s case, I do not want to play with hiding this visualization if nothing is selected totally. It will be marked with a title and e.g. column names but with no data reflected. The details will only be shown if we choose a row from the main table or a single slicer. In other words, we use the interaction between visualizations but also limit unnecessary information if nothing is filtered.

To achieve it we need to study two cases.

### First

Create a measure:

Choose one of the fields that you use in the main visualization as a  replacement for my DataSet Manufacturer.

Easy, almost there… now select the visual to be hidden, open the Filters Pane and place the measure onto the “Filters on this visual”, and set the “Show items when the value: is 1” and “Apply”.

This solution will be working only if data from the field you used in the measure occurs multiple times in the first visible visualization. If each category appears only once, we need to study the second case.
